text:

view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

AMY BANZAERT:
There were a couple of questions on estimations. So one person asked for
answers to estimations.

I try to give you orders of
magnitude and give you a sense, but if I missed some, if you
want to email me and be like,

hey, I never really got
this one, let me know, and I can review them. And then also,
the other thing is

I'm never going to give you a
6.7 answer because I'm really asking you an estimation
that has that kind of answer.

Like, some of them
do, but usually it's not even that important
that you get to 6.7.

It's important that you get to
an order of magnitude of 10. And as long as you're
there, I'm happy, and so that's why
I'm not getting

to the exact
answer, which I know is uncomfortable and not what
you're used to educationally,

but it's what the
estimation is there for. Another person mentioned
that some people

seem like they were
taking a really long time and getting lost
in the estimations. So I try to give you
the right amount of time

for the estimation so
that it's reasonable, but it is something to practice
getting more facile with,

I guess. All right, so wind energy. So does anyone know why
we have wind on the Earth?
Yeah. AUDIENCE: Because we have heat.

AMY BANZAERT: Yes, from? AUDIENCE: The Sun. AMY BANZAERT: Yes so
it's kind of funny because wind energy is basically
a funky solar energy, which

I find pleasing. I don't know why, but I do. There's also some Coriolis
effect stuff going around

on with the Earth rotating,
but the indirect solar energy component is more
easy to think about

and I think is the bigger
component, though I'm not sure of that. So basically, you have
uneven heating of the Earth,

hot air rises, causes a pressure
drop, cold air rushes in, and that movement is what
we're getting in wind.
So that's what's going on there.

And then a lot of
confusion sometimes happens-- like, a lot of people
see these turbines, or not

turbines, but mills on farms. And it's confusing. Like, what's this versus this? Is this just a junky
version of this?

And so the difference
is, if it's a mill, it's extracting mechanical
power, versus a turbine

is extracting electrical power. So these mills are very
high-torque devices

that move relatively slowly
in terms of their rotation and are used to do things like
pump water or grind grain.

They've been around forever. They're still really
common in the US and in many places
for pumping water.

So if you drive
across the country, you'll see these everywhere. And they're still
in use, and they're

really nice and a whole
lot cheaper to build a mill than to build a
turbine because you're

going from mechanical
work to mechanical work. So that's very direct
and much, much cheaper than doing the extra steps
to get from mechanical work

to electric power generation. So a wind turbine, in
contrast, is electrical power.

They have been around a long
time too, but not basically for most of humanity long time.

And again, they're going
to be moving very quickly at much lower torque.

The solidity thing
to think about is that when you
want high torque, you want to be getting
as much of the air

hitting your blades as possible. So that's why there's often
many, many blades or really thick blades on a windmill,
whereas a wind turbine,

you want low
solidity, so you want

a low proportion of your blade
to be in that swept area. So that's why a turbine is--
it looks very different.

So wind turbines, I'm
going to focus on,

but I will go back to windmills
a little bit at the end.

You have two types, right? The horizontal and
the vertical axis. The horizontal
axis is what you're

used to seeing around here
and what's in the news a lot because they can go to
much higher heights,

and wind is much better the
higher you go, basically.

And so the horizontal
wind axis turbines are the more common thing,
at least in my knowledge

before I started doing
any research into them. So there's the rotor and
the motor are at the top.

It has to point into the wind. The higher you go,
the better, but you

can imagine the higher you
go adds cost and difficulty.

You often try to
change your blade pitch to maximize the efficiency
because, depending

on how fast the wind is, you
want a different blade pitch. And they're now
really insanely huge.

[LAUGHS] So this is an insanely
huge 7-megawatt turbine,

which I think you
can see-- like,

is there a truck down
there or anything? It's hard to get scale
when it gets this big, but it's ridiculous.

And some of the challenges,
you can imagine, in building this thing is
just getting all the materials to the site because
you're probably

not going to build
your manufacturing plant of how you build your--

I'm still a little off-- that long blade, thank you. [LAUGHS] You're not going to build your
blade right on the site where

you're going to want to
install your turbine, probably, so then you have to
get your blade there. So then you're actually limited
by the size of a train railroad

car or a large
truck or whatever. So there's all these
crazy limits when you're

getting up to be this enormous. So it's kind of remarkable
and challenging,

and this is of a scale that
we're not going to be touching, of course, but it's nice
to see the extreme of what

is out there. So this is a 7-megawatt
turbine that's actually running now, I believe,
and they're currently

building a 10-megawatt that'll
be in production in a year or running in a year
or two, so which

is a pretty big jump, 7 to 10. So, yeah, it's definitely
an area that's taking off.

So how? This is just the classic
Bernoulli drawing

to remind you how they're
spinning in the wind and that the motion is
really dominated by the lift,

not drag. One thing to think about is the
need to control the spin rate.

So you can imagine on days
where there's not much wind,

you might want to change
the pitch of the blade to make sure you're maximizing
the wind you're capturing.

But on hurricane days,
you have to make sure

that your wind turbine doesn't
completely just spin out of control.

And so this is a really nice,
relatively simple way to do it. So you can do it
mechanically or electrically,

or you can do it manually. So with old windmills
from 100 or 200 years ago,

there was some
poor guy whose job it was to turn the windmill
into the wind or not,

depending on how fast. It was so thankfully,
there's been ways to optimize that either
mechanically or electrically.

So this is a method where
basically the weight

of the tail and the
turbine allows the tail to stay connected to the
turbine so that the tail--

I'm getting lots of confused
faces, so I'll go slowly. So the turbine
generally has a tail

that's exactly perpendicular. So this plane and
the plane of the tail

are perpendicular so
that the tail makes sure it's always pointing
into the wind, which is what you want, except
when you're going too fast.

Now you need the tail and
the front of the turbine to not be perpendicular
but to start to--

hypothetically, if
you're in gales, you need it to be completely
rotated so that the wind is

just passing by the turbine. Or if you're in a
moderate wind, where it's too fast for the
turbine but still usable,

you want it to be
off a little bit. And so the way this works is
that when the wind speed gets

high enough, you get some
lift in either the tail or the turbine. I forget how it
operates exactly.

And so that allows this
tail stop to be disengaged. So then the turbine
rotates a little bit, which

you can see from this top view. These are the front views,
and this is the top view. So then the turbine
rotates a little bit,

and then the weight
balances out. And so then the
top engages again, and then it maintains
this angle of orientation.

And then if the wind
speed gets even higher, again, the weights will get out
of balance, things will lift,

the stop will disengage. So it's a really cool system
to keep your device safe,

and there's a lot
of them out there. And so I just wanted to show
an example of what happens

when you don't remember-- where's my mouse-- to include
that or don't do it right.
So watch carefully.

So that was an expensive,
day and they're really lucky that no
one was under there.

So I'll put it back so
you can watch it again. Can you see? Were you saying
couldn't see, Jess?

[INTERPOSING VOICES] AMY BANZAERT: Did you
make it work, or-- AUDIENCE: The blade
just fell off. AMY BANZAERT: What? AUDIENCE: Did the
blade just fall off?

Like, did it just-- AMY BANZAERT: So
it rotated so fast that I believe one of
the blades broke off.

And then once one breaks,
it's totally out of balance, and the whole thing
just falls apart.

And it's moving
at such fast speed that really crazy
dynamics are going on.

So, yeah, so
there's really solid reasons to design these
right, especially when

you're talking big scale. But even small scale, you
can imagine in a hurricane,

it's not going to be a
safe thing to be near, and the small ones
are often near people.

OK, so the typical components
of a wind turbine--

you have your rotor. You have your blades. You have a brake because you
want the turbine to be turning

at a certain speed, ideally. And so you may need to
brake, provide braking, before you're providing
rotation out of the wind.

That's another smaller
step you can take. You have a gearbox to get
the speed to the right speed

to power your generator. Typically, on a
fancier wind turbine, there's an anemometer that
provides the electrical control

with these yaw drives and
motors to rotate the turbine into the wind or out
of the wind to maximize

the speed of your turbine
and then your tower. And then so all
the electricity is

being generated in
this part of the body, and then the power is
just going down the tower.

And you can imagine
the challenge of when you need to do
maintenance on this, and you're talking
about something really

high up that you
have to deal with it. So the smaller turbines
that we'll be looking at, they're all on guide
wires and on a pivot

so that you can
rotate them down so you don't have to climb up to
do maintenance because that requires a much sturdier
tower and is a much more

dangerous job. Some installation considerations
that one would think

would be obvious
but aren't always-- so this is a wind turbine
that's been installed basically

on a rooftop by some trees. So it's got two
types of objects that

are blocking the wind entirely. So this was a
many-thousand-dollar installation that's probably
providing zero electricity

because the wind may be
sufficient 30 meters up, but right there is never
going to be sufficient.

So the good-- 30 meters, 30 feet. A good rule of thumb is
you want your turbine

to be 30 feet above any
obstruction within 300 feet. And so obstructions include
houses and plants and anything

else that might be in the way. So next up is vertical-axis
wind turbines,

and you can see there's
a huge range of them. And you probably haven't seen
most of these in production

because, again, they don't have
the same level of efficiencies

and benefits that
horizontal-axis wind turbines have. But they're a whole lot
cheaper and easier to build.

So for small-scale solutions,
they can be really ideal. There's a bunch of different
names of these different types.

So, for example, this is
called a Darrieus wind turbine. This is a Savonius
wind turbine, which you'll be building on Friday.

And this is a cool
combo, Savonius-Darrieus. The Savonius will start
up automatically in wind,

and the won't but
the Darrieus gets a little bit better efficiency. So that combining
sort of gets you

the best of both worlds with
some drawbacks, of course, too. And so these power
traffic lights in Taiwan.

So there are places where these
are installed effectively.

And they're kind of cool
because, as you can see here,

you can almost build
them out of anything, and you will build them
out of anything on Friday. Hey, Amit, do we have
enough plastic bottles,

speaking of which, for Friday? AMIT GANDHI: [INAUDIBLE] AMY BANZAERT: So
added to your homework

is, on Friday, you need to
bring in a plastic bottle, like a Gatorade bottle, a
2-liter bottle, whatever.

It doesn't have to be 2 liters. It can be 1 liter or
a 20-ounce bottle,

but we need plastic bottles. So if everyone brings one,
we'll be in good shape. Is that doable?

If you check the recycling
bins walking to class, you'll find one. [LAUGHS] Cool. So some of the advantages,
they're closer to the ground,

so you don't have any
line losses compared to the horizontal-axis
wind turbine.

You don't need any
yaw or pitch control because they're
just in the wind. They're intended to be in
the wind, and that works.

And they work generally
for lower wind speeds, which means lower heights. They are often much less noisy
than horizontal-axis wind

turbines, and they can
often start at lower speeds. But some of the disadvantages,
they're hard to scale up.

So you're never going to get a
7-megawatt vertical-axis wind

turbine. That's just not viable. They're generally
less efficient, and they're more
prone to fatigue,

so they do wear out more
easily because they're capturing so much more
of the wind, typically.

But for our purposes,
they're definitely a possibility to look at.

For anything, just a
reminder of the equations

we're thinking about-- so the force that
you're receiving

is equivalent to 1/2
times rho Av squared.

So v is obviously the
velocity of the wind, the cross-sectional area swept,
and the density of the wind.

The maximum possible
power extraction

is dominated by
the velocity cubed.

So, obviously, velocity is
going to be-- your wind velocity is really going to
be what you worry

about when you're designing. So area is important, obviously,
but the velocity's cubed,

so the wind speed is huge. So whenever you're
thinking, is this a place where the velocity--

is a wind turbine appropriate? The first question is,
well, what's the wind speed?

And then there's a
coefficient of performance, which just is a reality that
wind turbines are not perfect.

And so there's a
hypothetical limit. And if you google
the best limit, you can find the proof that's
appealing-- it's kind of cool--

of almost 0.6 is your
hypothetical maximum efficiency. And then a typical limit in
reality is anywhere from 1/2

for a really sweet
horizontal-axis wind turbine to less than 1/10 for a
vertical-axis wind turbine

that I'll show you later
that's really old school but does the job
when you need it.

So the other equation that
you want to think about is the capacity factor. So I've seen some
websites that say, wind

is so much better than
solar because wind is 24/7. Well, not really.

[LAUGHS] Like, unless
you're getting up way into the atmosphere--
and even then, there's a lot of variation--

wind is not 24/7. There's a tremendous
amount of variation. And so it's generally
20% to 40% of the time

is how often your
turbine is generating power, which is starting
to sound more like solar,

actually. So that's one thing to
definitely keep in mind.

OK, so a typical power curve-- so at some point,
at some given speed

is when the turbine
starts actually turning because, up until then,
it can't physically turn because the wind
forces aren't high enough.

And then your output in terms
of power is very, very low.

And then you have an
average wind speed that's generally somewhere
around here, which is giving you half of the
wind power or the power

that you'd like. And then you have a
maximum wind speed,

and then you're
happy, happy, happy. And then at some
point, it gets so high that you have to shut
the turbine down,

or else you're in trouble. So that's just a
good general way

to think about what's happening
over different speeds because-- I'll show you later, we're
going to look at data that

shows you the different speeds. So these are maps from
NASA that show wind speed

across the entire globe. And you can see if it's very
dark, it's very low wind speed.

And if it's very light,
it's higher wind speed. So if we could just fill
this part of the ocean

with wind turbines, that
would be pretty sweet. But you can actually
see in Nicaragua,

which is right over here, you're
getting pretty decent wind. Compared to, say,
if we were working

in these parts of Africa or up
here in Russia or something, we wouldn't be thinking
wind turbines at all.

And you can see how
much variation there is between January and July. And so, of course, there's
a lot of seasonal variation,

no matter what. And you can see this blue
is 7 meters per second,

which is getting to be useful. For a horizontal-axis
wind turbine, you need 5 meters per second.

For vertical, you can
go a little bit lower, but 5 is a good rule of thumb.

And again, why we're looking at
velocity over everything else is because velocity is cubed
for your power equation.

So great, I've told
you wind speeds. I've showed you a NASA
map of the entire Earth,

but that doesn't tell you
much for a given location. So one way to get a really
rough estimate of wind speed

is this Beaufort scale, which
was developed in the 1800s. And it correlates what
you can visually see

and what kind of damage
you're seeing to the speed. Some of the caveats on this are
number one, it's pretty rough.

And especially if
you're talking to people in a community saying,
tell me about wind speed, and giving them examples,
it's hard to remember

exactly what the wind is like. Like, can you tell me what
the Beaufort scale was today walking here?

I can't. [LAUGHS] I don't remember. I don't really pay attention
to the wind that much. If you're working
with farmers, they're

probably a little bit more aware
of it than you and I might be, but still, it's challenging. And the other thing is
that a lot of these metrics

are on the ground,
and we're probably talking about significantly
higher than the ground, depending on what kind of
turbine you're implementing.

And so again, that
only helps you. So if you're finding
out that you're probably

at 4 miles an hour, which is
2 meters per second and really

low, but at the
very ground level, and you're building a
turbine that's 30 feet up,

maybe you have a shot
of getting enough wind. Yeah. AUDIENCE: Just a quick question.

Is there a uniform
scale from what the wind speed at
the ground level is and how it changes vertically?

Or is that a regional
thing like you said? AMY BANZAERT:
Well, so it's both. So yes, there are
some scales that

can help you estimate, if
you know what the ground is, what it is up above. But it also is really
dependent on what's around.

And so I'm about to
show you a tool that helps a little bit with that,
but it's still very imperfect.

Ideally, you'd
have an anemometer, and you leave it
up for five years, and you'd have it at 10
different heights, 10

different anemometers, 10
different heights, and that would give you actual real
data that you'd be psyched for.

But that would be a
really ridiculously slow, expensive project. And so a lot of this
is just estimations

and doing your best guesses. So this, I'm sorry
for the web link.

As you'll see, this
website is web-- it's not even web 1.0. It's like web 0.5.

But it has awesome
data from NASA. So you go to this website
with that awful link,

and then there's a
bunch of different ways to get this data. And this is actually both
useful for solar and wind.

So if you're worrying
about solar data too, this is really useful. So if you don't know your
latitude and longitude,

you can click, use
the map to click. Every time you do this,
you have to log in,

but it's very easy to
join because you just type your password twice instead
of once you become a member.

And then it's slow,
but it looks so clunky

that I was afraid you'd
be turned off by it. And it has good enough
data that I wanted to go through showing you it.

So you have this
map of the Earth. You click in the
part of the Earth that you care
about to center it.

You click to zoom.  We're in the wrong part of the
world, but we're getting there.

I'm going to zoom in again.  And you can see like this
is data for a region,

not for a small town. So there's all sorts of limits
to this data, but it's useful.

And so now you can
finally get your data, and now you can get
crazy information--

so parameters for solar
cooking, for solar panels,

cloud information, which
can be really useful, temperature, which
can be really useful.

And now we're getting to wind. So you can see the variety. So you can get 50
meter and 10 meter,

but because this is all
satellite data or airport data-- so 50 meters is pretty high for
anything we're talking about,

and then 10 meters for
terrain similar to the airport because they're
measuring at the airport

because that's the place
where they have anemometers. So all of this data,
again, you have to take with a grain
of salt, but it's

good to-- if you use
that in conjunction with your own visual
observations in talking to people, it's better
than nothing, which

is the alternative for a
million-dollar 10-year study, which isn't viable either.

So we're going to just
look at wind speed at 50 meters for that area
of Nicaragua I just selected.

And you can see
a 10-year average and a minimum and
maximum variation.

So it's pretty helpful just to
get you into the ballpark of, do I have a shot of
thinking this might work?

And then some of the other
things that you can select for are how high you are--

so, Jessica, this is getting to
what you were interested in-- like, an estimate of where you
are and what your ground cover

is, and then it extrapolates
what the wind will be. So it's pretty
useful and powerful.

Is it 100% accurate,
given that it's doing really broad-based readings?

Of course not, but it's a start. So it's a nice
resource to know about.

So now I want to
spend a little time to talk about examples of wind
power in developing countries.

So one is the
Humdinger Windbelt, which is totally different
from what you're used to seeing

and was developed by a
student who actually took one of the first D-Lab
classes back when

it was the Haiti class. And we have a Windbelt here,
but I couldn't find it, so maybe during break,
I'll be able to dig it up.

Or if not, maybe we
can bring it by Friday and show it in lab on Friday.

So the way the Windbelt works
is that instead of a rotation,

it just uses the vibration of
the belt, very similar to--

I don't if you guys
can remember the name

of the bridge that collapsed. AUDIENCE: Tacoma Narrow. AMY BANZAERT: Yeah. Does everyone know that
Tacoma Narrows Bridge?

Yeah, so, well, google it
because you can see videos, and it's awesome if you haven't.

So, yeah, it is totally
scary, especially because--

I have a friend who did
some research into it. And so this bridge was
a super long bridge,

and it just had natural
frequencies at the same rate

as the wind was often blowing. And so the bridge would
just go up and down

and up and down crazily. And eventually, one
day, it got so bad that it completely broke apart.

And the crazy thing
is that people used to hang out on the bridge
on the really windy days because it was so fun.

It was like a roller coaster. And so it's extra scary
thinking about that. So anyway, but this
is the inspiration

for the Humdinger, which just
has a really tightly pulled belt in the middle of a
support structure so that the--

and you put this wind, so the
wind is going perpendicular to the board. And so that hits the natural
frequencies of the belt

and causes it to vibrate. And then you just have
some magnets next to a coil

on the corner that allow
you to generate electricity. So for certain
applications, this

can be a really low-cost
way to provide electricity. And this is a pretty
relatively fancy way

of building it, but you
can imagine, and they have, building it out of
like a PVC pipe, which you can get anywhere,
and building it really simply.

And because there's very
few moving parts and nothing rotating, it's much
easier to build than even

a vertical-axis wind turbine. And so it's a really
neat application. And hypothetically, you
could imagine building it

into structures like railings
on buildings and stuff

in order to power
different things. So this is one example. And we do have at
least a couple D-Labs,

so we'll make sure to show you
them later today or tomorrow. Another example is the
classic wind turbine

in developing countries was
designed by Hugh Piggott. And these are pictures of work
being done at blueEnergy, which

is in Bluefields in Nicaragua,
and we worked with them last year, and they
build all these turbines.

So you can see there's
the support wires and that you can rotate the
turbine down so that you

can do maintenance on it,
which is a really nice feature. So that's one
classic design that's

pretty common in
developing countries. And then a lot of people have
heard of William Kamkwamba.

Oh, there's the Windbelt,
so let me go back to that. So I'll pass this around,
and the belt is not

exactly taught at the moment. But you can see just the belt,
the magnet on the belt that

goes against the
coil, and that's really all there is to it, and
then a little bit of circuitry in order to generate power,
which is a really simple way

to do things. AUDIENCE: So what's the idea? The wind blows through
the tape there? AMY BANZAERT: Yeah.

And the tape vibrates just
its natural frequencies, and the vibration allows
you to generate electricity. It's movement is all you need.
Thanks. [LAUGHS]

So William Kamkwamba
was this guy--
where did he live? Did I write it down--

in Malawi, and he just got
really interested in how he could get electricity at his
house, and went to the library,

and read a bunch of
books, and got inspired, and built his own
wind turbine, which

doesn't look like your
traditional wind turbine. There are a few
design improvements

that could be made, especially
with better resources. But worked well enough
for him to power

a radial at his house
and charge cell phones, which got people really excited
so that they would start

paying him, so he
could start building more and more turbines.

So it's a really cool story,
and now he's at Dartmouth,

in school, which he'd never
could have done had he not built this turbine. So he's a cool guy.

We may be able to get him to
come down to talk to our class this year. We'll see.

I'm trying. But his advisor at
Dartmouth is very reluctant to let him travel. [LAUGHS] I'm sorry?

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] AMY BANZAERT: Yeah. But because he
didn't grow up here, he's getting very parented
at a different level

than you guys are by the
professor at Dartmouth.

So anyway, so just a cool
example of something very low tech that worked
really well and made

a remarkable change for this
guy and also his village.

And then working
all the way down to the really simplest wind
turbines, so this is a--

I don't if you say it
as "pah-neh-mo-nee" or "pa-neh-mone,"
but one of those--

wind turbine, which is
incredibly old technology. This is the 10,000-BC technology
that we're talking about,

and it's just sails that rotate. The sails-- actually, each
one rotates 180 degrees, So.

They're always
moving in the wind. And this is not a turbine. This is a mill.

So the act of it spinning
pulls this rope pump. Maybe if I turn off the
lights, it'll be easier to see.

So there's a rope pump,
here, and the way a rope pump works is incredibly simple. You just have a rope inside
a tube that goes down

into the water table so
that you're getting water

through holes in the tube. And then you either
have knots in the rope or, if you can find
them, rubber washers

every foot along the tube. And this is obviously
not to scale in any way.

And so the water gets
trapped between the washers, and you pull up
the water that way.

And so this is really simple. Again, we're talking about
ridiculously low efficiencies. But if you need

So hydropower is just using

considering both--

the two terms I'm going to

So head is the distance that the
water falls, and then flow rate is how quickly the
water is moving.

And so hydropower can be at
2 megawatts and much beyond

and is a sizable impact on our
nation's electricity supply,

Again, they're low
velocity, high torque, delivering mechanical
power directly,

as opposed to a turbine,
which is much higher velocity, much lower
torque to allow
you to generate electricity. So those are the two extremes. Yeah.

In terms of hydropower,
there's two methods. So one is called
run of the river,

and that means that you're just
taking a chunk of the river

and siphoning it
off into a tube that goes directly into your turbine,
and the other option is a dam.

So the benefits of this are
that it's relatively simple. You can build it
locally, compared

to a dam is much harder
to build generally. It's comparatively much
lower environmental impact

than a dam. They're relatively affordable. But when you have a drought,
you don't have any storage

like you have with a dam,
so that's the drawback.

And the dam is the reverse,
that you can accumulate your rainfall, which is great,
but it's relatively expensive,

And. There's a greater
environmental impacts on the negative
because damming up

water affects the
local environment, from the fish to just what the
fields look like, et cetera, et

cetera. I'm sure you've heard
of dams in China are similar that have destroyed
entire communities for building

dams on a very,
very large scale.

Yeah, and there's
more maintenance associated with the dam, too,
in terms of silt accumulation. It's challenging.

So we're just going to talk
about the run of the river model. So the components that
you have is something

called a weir that diverts
a chunk of the water into your tube.

You generally have
a settling basin so that any debris
settles out because you

don't want it going
into your turbine because you'll
destroy your turbine. A forebay, which
is a small holding

tank-- so you're getting
reserve capacity that way, but that's talking
about variation on the order of seconds or
minutes, not days or months.

Penstock, which is a closed
pipe flowing downhill-- that feeds directly into your
turbine that then generates

your electricity,
and then the water is returned back to the river.

is called a Pelton wheel. And you can see it's got a
relatively complex geometry,

and so relatively expensive
and challenging to build. But if you do, it's
very efficient.

It works well for a
high-head, low-flow situation. So again, head is how far
the water is dropping.

Francis wheels,
which work better for lower head, higher flow,
which has a spiral casing where

the water comes in and
spins this turbine and then comes out.

Cross-flow, where the water
flows over this cylinder,

which has a bunch
of blades on it, and that's what spins the
shaft to generate electricity.

A propeller, which literally
uses a ship's propeller, and instead of the ship's
propeller being powered

in order to move the
boat, it's just using it in the exact opposite way.

And you can see that you need
different types of turbines for different flow
and head situations.

And then one example

that's your only option, or it can work.

you need for micro hydro--

one is that the minimum head and
flow you need is 3 feet of head

and 20 gallons per

And if you have more
head, either, bonus,

you get more power,
or you can therefore have reduced flow because the
power equation here is, again,

a coefficient of
efficiency times the water density
and gravity times

the height, which is your head,
and Q, which is your flow rate. So you can see that hQ,
you can keep constant.

If you increase your head,
you can lower your velocity, and keep your power constant.

One nice just rule of thumb
is if you stick with SI units, rho g is about 10.

So you can just plug that
in rather than having to remember the density

And then efficiency is somewhere

if your pipe diameter

so much that it's problematic. So that's another
thing to remember because it's tempting to
use small-diameter pipe

micro hydro? So the two things you need to
know, again, are flow and head. So the simplest method I
can find for measuring flow

is called a float method. And you can imagine actually
doing this in a river would be challenging,
so it's not trivial,

but it is possible. So you mark about 100
feet along a length

that's ideally straight with
uniform width and depth, which

is comical to find
in a river, right? Like, I've never
found a river that

has 100 feet of uniform
width and depth, but you do your best. And then you calculate your
cross-sectional area A. People

usually model it as a
semicircle, or a trapezoid,

or even just a
rectangle, calculate that cross-sectional area.

You place a marker at the
start and end of your 100 feet, and then you put
floats in the river

at the center of the stream
and time them to find out how long it takes for them to
get from one end to the other.

If you want to get
complicated, you can put them all along a
bunch of different points

at different levels to
worry about friction losses, but you don't actually have
to do that to get a ballpark

measurement. You can just do
it in the center. And so good floats
could be a tennis ball,

could be an apple, or
something like that, whatever you can find that floats. And then you do have to
use a conversion factor

because your water is flowing
faster at the top of the water than in the--

river than in the center
because of the friction associated with the
base of the river.

And so you can use a
coefficient just to correct,

and then you get your flow rate. Yay. So that was a lot
